ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We had live virtual lectures and discussions 3 days a week and were assigned asynchronous work 2 days a week.
3 days a week were live virtual lectures, and 2 days a week were completely asynchronous
Virtual seminar with asynchronous classes on Tuesdays and Thursdays
Recorded lectures tues and thurs most of the time.
none

In this class, Professor Reymundi would teach the material and then allow us to practice our speaking in breakout rooms. We had a lot of homework activities and readings that helped improve vocabulary.
asynchronous learning on Tuesdays and Thursdays
The best format for me was an in-person, recorded lecture that broke out into a small group discussion among peers before coming back and having a large group discussion.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about spanish grammar concepts and writing.
The ability to write, speak, listen to, and understand spanish. I was able to communicate with fellow students in spanish.
I improved practice speaking and using the techniques I had learned in L2
got better at spanish
I improved my vocabulary and and practiced my speaking abilities. We often went into breakout rooms to practice conversing with each other in Spanish which helped prepare us for the final.
I have further honed by speaking, writing, and listening skills during this course. I've also developed a better knowledge of the grammar.

I believe this course developed my communication skills a lot. I now have an easier time communicating my thoughts either through writing or speech. It is still not grammatically perfect, but it is a huge improvement compared to my skills before the class.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the supersite homework was helpful in giving us the opportunity for lots of practice. I also liked the grammar presentations and lectures from the professor. I think my speaking would have improved more if we had more chances in class or even for homework to do activities where we had to speak the language.
Languages are very difficult over Zoom. It was difficult to feel engaged with the class or with the material. I think at times the material felt very erratic and disconnected.
It was good that all the lectures were mandatory because I was forced to be exposed to spanish and I think I improved a lot. It sucks though because I was on the west coast so it was at 7:30 AM.

Strengths-- very engaging, a lot of work to solidify knowledge of language
Weaknesses-- difficult to fully grasp a concept because questions would be answered in Spanish

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Having to take tests and homework assignments through canvas was not ideal for grammar concepts and I think made them a bit more challenging and stressful with all the technology and moving parts.
Overall, this class worked very well remotely.
I think the asynchronous classes are not incredibly productive and wish we had met in person every day.
Tuesdays and Thursdays off was a good idea because Zoom fatigue is real.
MORE SECTION TIMES FOR PEOPLE ON DIFFERENT TIME ZONES.

We often went into breakout rooms to practice skills in small groups. We would present projects to each other using the share screen feature on Zoom. The professor always asked if anyone had questions and would clarify anything that was confusing with the whole class.
Breakout rooms were very beneficial to the overall learning experience

I really enjoyed the breakout room sessions. The teacher-less space made speaking less focused on proving that you can remember all of the grammatical structures and more on actually communicating your thoughts.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend for anyone interested in learning a lot of spanish grammar concepts and applying them in writing. If you want to progress your spanish I think it would be good to take. However, if you are looking to work on speaking and fluency in conversation I would not recommend.
Only if you need to take it to complete the language requirement
Definitely, this course is awesome, and also Prof. Reymundi is the GOAT. Def take with her.
Yes. A lot of exposure to spanish.
Yes, this is a  phenomenal course to further learn Spanish. The class is very engaging and the professors are very attentive and helpful.
